QTEXT: Q1. What is the function of area A?
QA: A. To choose words and vocalise them.
QB: B. To listen to words and understand them.
QC: C. To inhibit socially inappropriate behaviour.
QD: D. To process sensory information from the periphery.
ANS: A. To choose words and vocalise them.
REA: Remember, this is Broca's area in the frontal lobe and it is the motor speech area. The sensory speech area is known as Wernicke's area and it is in the temporal lobe.

QTEXT: Q2. What is the name of structure B?
REA: This is lateral sulcus, or Sylvian fissure, that separates the temporal lobe from the frontal and parietal lobes.

QTEXT: Q3. What is the name of area C?
REA: This is the primary visual cortex located in the posterior portion of the occipital lobe. It receives images from the retina upside-down, then flips them around.

QTEXT: Q4. What is the name of area D?
REA: This is the sensory association cortex (responsible for processing body sensations). Note that Brodmann divided this area up again, so calling this whole area the sensory association cortex is somewhat a generalisation.

QTEXT: Q5. In which gyrus is area E located?
REA: Area E is the primary motor cortex, located just in front of the central sulcus, i.e. the precentral gyrus.
